# Criminal Law Outline

*This case is all about x. The prosecution will probably charge x with x for killing x, with the mens rea of x, as the prosecution will try to apply x statute to negate x defense.* 

**ASSUMING ARGUENDO (arguing in the alternativeâ€¦ even if initial thought was wrong, backup thought is this) that affirmative defense fails, the defense will attempt to lower the homicide charge to x â€“ good phrase\!\!**

# Fact Pattern

## Checklist of Arguments

**KEY TIPS:**

* Check the **mens rea / actus reus** of the different degrees of charges that are available â€“ CLEARLY EXPLAIN the different mens rea / actus reus and explain why the defendant falls under the one(s) chosen  
* Can have **multiple charges for the same person** based on the effect of their interactions with different people (killed one, recklessly endangered others)  
* **READ HIS MODIFIED STATUTES CLOSELY**  
  * If they do not have a mens rea explicitly listed, **then presumption is reckless or above â€“ clearly state this presumption** and then see if the statute applies  
    * HE WILL TRY TO TRICK YOU\!\! Just because the actus reus is the same does NOT mean the mens rea automatically applies

**Prosecution** 

* **1\) Actus reus**   
  * Issue of causation   
    * For an act to be considered **proximate cause** of the injury, the injury must be the actual result of the act â€“ *People v. Acosta* â€“ PROXIMATE CAUSE TEST:  
      * 1\. Was defendantâ€™s conduct the actual cause of the injury?  
        * Yes ğŸ¡ª move forward with examination  
        * No ğŸ¡ª no proximate causation   
      * 2\. Was the result an intended consequence of the defendantâ€™s conduct?  
        * Yes ğŸ¡ª proximate cause  
        * No ğŸ¡ª 3\. Was the defendantâ€™s conduct a substantial factor in the harm?  
          * No ğŸ¡ª no proximate cause  
          * Yes ğŸ¡ª proximate cause UNLESS the result was highly extraordinary  
    * An individual is criminally liable if his conduct is a **sufficiently direct cause** of anotherâ€™s death which should have been foreseen as being reasonably related to the individualâ€™s acts â€“ *People v. Arzon*  
* **2\) Mens rea**  
  * \*\*Presumption is recklessness if the statute does not specify\*\*  
  * Defendant acts with **implied malice** if the defendantâ€™s conduct carries a high probability of death and the defendant consciously disregards this risk  
* Homicide charge spec.:  
  * **W ADDITIONAL FELONY** (or attempt or accomplice) ğŸ¡ª goes from manslaughter to murder  
  * **EXTREME EMOTIONAL DISTRESS** ğŸ¡ª goes from murder to manslaughter  
* EXPANDING LIABILITY:  
  * Attempt   
  * Complicity  
  * Conspiracy  
* Defendant not liable for injury to co-defendant when caused by person resisting the felony / murder / etc. â€“ *State v. Canola*   
* \*When involving police officer (either force *against* officer or force *by* officer) â€“ did others have reason to know that this individual was an officer??\*

**Defense** 

* Are the actus reus and mens rea actually met??  
* If law enforcement, was the use of force justified? MPC Â§3.07  
* **THROW IN ALL POSSIBLE DEFENSES**  
* **JUSTIFICATIONS**  
  * Self-Defense â€“ MPC Â§3.04  
    * Duty to retreat beforehand? Nowadays, retreat tends to be the default but there are some exceptions that allow SYG:  
    * Perfect v. Imperfect Self-Defense â€“ *State v. Norman*  
    * Battered Women Syndrome (also *State v. Norman*)  
  * Necessity / Choice of Lesser Evils â€“ MPC Â§3.02  
* **EXCUSES**  
  * Necessity / Duress â€“ MPC Â§2.09  
  * Insanity â€“ MPC Â§4.01  
    * Incl. addiction to alcohol / drugs, in which it could also be argued that actions were not voluntary   
      * Cannot get in trouble for the status of being addicted, so must have engaged in some other act while addicted that is illegal â€“ *Robinson v. California*   
  * **\*\*Extreme Emotional Distress\*\* (HARCOURT LOVES THIS)**  
  * Heat of Passion (typ. When men find out their wives have cheated)   
* A2 EXPANDING LIABILITY â€“ Defense of Withdrawal / Renunciation  
  * A2 Attempt  
  * A2 Complicity  
  * A2 Conspiracy  
  * **ALWAYS try to lower the underlying offense,** even though it was not conducted by the defendant in question

**Prosecution Response**

* **A2 JUSTIFICATIONS**  
  * A2 Self-Defense  
  * A2 Necessity   
* **A2 EXCUSES**  
  * A2 Duress   
  * A2 Insanity  
    * A2 Not Voluntary due to alcohol / drugs â€“ choice to take the alcohol / drugs to begin with *was* voluntary â€“ *Powell v. Texas*  
  * A2 Extreme Emotional Distress

## Attempt, Complicity, and Conspiracy

|  | Attempt | Complicity | Conspiracy  |
| :---- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **Mens Rea** | What intent is required? Specific intent or Same as the underlying offense Can one recklessly commit an attempt of an intentional crime? Can one attempt a reckless or negligent crime?  | Several possibilities: Same mens rea as the principal Mens rea is to â€œaidâ€ principal Knows principalâ€™s mens rea Knows principalâ€™s mens rea and actus reus | Agreement to conspire (with exceptions) and Complicated mens rea issues  |
| **Actus Reus** | What does D need to have done? First step Last step Substantial step Withdrawal  | How much do you have to aid/abet to be complicit? Must aid or abet; mere presence is not enough  | Overt act requirement  |
| **Punishment**  | How much do you punish? Separate crime at Â½ grade below or Same punishment (MPC: considers an unsuccessful criminal just as dangerous as a successful one)  | How much do you punish? Same as principal  Accessory after the crime is subject to less punishment  | Separate offense, so two convictions (1 for doing the crime, 1 for conspiring to commit the crime) Lots of benefits for prosecution. Fixed term (5) or tied to object crime |

**Attempt (MPC Â§5.01)**

* **Mens Rea** of intent is TRICKY â€“ debate over whether there needs to be specific intent to commit the crime (that ended up not coming to fruition) or intent to engage in the underlying conduct   
  * MPC outlines 3 avenues under Â§5.01(1) â€“ 1\) engages in conduct (purpose), 2\) causes a particular result (with belief ğŸ¡ª knowledge), or 3\) act or omission done purposefully that is a substantial step towards the crime (purpose, as defined in Â§5.01(2))  
    * For all 3, need whatever type of culpability the crime specifies  
* Think about the difference between intent to cause a knowing death (intent to do a different act that you know will result in someoneâ€™s death) v. intent to directly cause a death itself v. intent to commit a different act that you did not suspect would cause death  
* **Actus Reus** differs based on jurisdiction â€“ last act v. first step  
  * MPC outlines 3 avenues under Â§5.01(1), with different actus reus highlighted above  
  * Â§5.01(2) defines what acts constitute â€œsubstantial stepâ€  
* **Defense of Withdrawal** â€“ MPC Â§5.01(4)  
  * â€œIt is an affirmative defense that he abandoned his effort to commit the crime or otherwise prevented its commission, under circumstances manifesting a **complete and voluntary renunciation of his criminal purpose**.  The establishment of such defense does not, however, affect the liability of an accomplice who did not join in such abandonment or prevention.â€  
* Complicity and attempt can join to make attempted complicity, such that one is charged with attempted felony *through* complicity â€“ MPC Â§5.01(3)   
* Punishment is the same as the actual crime itself

**Complicity (MPC Â§2.06)**

* NOT charged with the crime of aiding and abetting; rather, charged with the actual crime itself through the *act* of aiding and abetting â€“ other personâ€™s crime becomes your own due to the fact that you aided and abetted them  
* **Mens Rea**  
  * MPC Â§2.06(3)(a) really flows out of Â§2.06(2)(c) and defines accomplice with a mens rea of purpose â€“ â€œpurpose of promoting or facilitating the commission of the offenseâ€ by soliciting someone to do it, aiding someone in planning or doing it, or not stopping someone from doing it when there is a legal duty to do so  
* **Actus Reus**  
  * Conduct the same acts that would establish liability under the ultimate offense  
  * For offenses that have a particular result as an element of the offense, complicity is established if the individual acts with the same kind of culpability with respect to the result that is sufficient for the commission of the offense â€“ Â§2.06(4)   
    * *Commonwealth v. Roebuck* **â€“** very important for unintentional homicide cases because they are result-based crimes, BUT you can take acts *intentionally* with someone else that *unintentionally* result in death  
  * *State v. Gladstone* â€“ have to carefully distinguish which act the person was complicit in  
* **Accessory after the fact** is the one form of aiding that does **not** merge with the actual act â€“ it is treated as a separate criminal responsibility  
* No need for the principal actor to be convicted for the accomplice to be convicted â€“ MPC Â§2.06(7) ğŸ¡ª principal can be acquitted but accomplice is convicted\!  
  * Ex. principal is acquitted on insanity defense, which accomplice does not have  
* Key is to ask yourself what you have to prove based on the relationship between the defendant and the principal, and the defendant and the crime  
* **Defense of Withdrawal** â€“ MPC Â§2.06(6)(c)  
  * Not an accomplice if individual 1\) terminates his complicity **AND** 2\) wholly deprives it of effectiveness OR 3\) gives timely warning to law enforcement or makes some other proper effort to prevent commission of the offense   
  * Also not an accomplice if individual is a victim of the offense â€“ 2.06(6)(a) 

**Conspiracy (MPC Â§5.03)**

* Separate crime of conspiracy ğŸ¡ª crime does not *have* to have been completed (inchoate); if completed (choate), there are 2 separate convictions and offenses, one for conspiracy and the other for the offense  
* **Actus Reus**  
  * Agreement â€“ MPC Â§5.03(1), *Interstate Circuit, Inc. v. US*  
  * Overt act â€“ MPC Â§5.03(5)  
* **Mens Rea**  
  * Knowledge of nature of activity  
  * Intent or inferred intent â€“ *People v. Lauria*   
    * Definitely needed for misdemeanors   
    * *May* be needed for felonies, but sometimes knowledge is enough to serve as implied intent to agree with the crime  
* 3 ways to **INFER** intent from a business â€“ *People v. Lauria*  
  * 1\. Supplier of services has a stake in the venture  
  * 2\. There is no legitimate use for the goods or services taking place  
  * 3\. Volume of business with the buyer is grossly disproportionate to any legitimate demand / sales for the illegal use are a high proportion of the supplierâ€™s total business  
* **MPC REJECTS THIS,** but theoretically can also be charged under conspiratorial accomplice liability, aka for crimes committed by co-conspirators *even though* those crimes were not part of the original conspiracy â€“ *Pinkerton v. US*  
  * **BRING THIS UP** but then say MPC does not allow  
* **Defense of Renunciation** â€“ Â§5.03(6)  
  * Successful affirmative defense if actor â€œthwarted the success of the conspiracy, under circumstances manifesting a complete and voluntary renunciation of his criminal purposeâ€  
* Benefits to state of conspiracy charge  
  * Admit hearsay evidence  
  * Conduct joint trial  
  * More options for location of trial  
  * Cumulative punishment  
  * Charge with conspiratorial accomplice liability / *Pinkerton* rule  
  * Statute of limitations â€“ duration of conspiracy outlined in Â§5.03(7)

## Justifications

**Self-Defense (MPC Â§3.04)**

* Â§3.04(2)(b) limits use of deadly force to only situations where actor believes such force â€œis necessary to protect himself against death, serious bodily injury, kidnapping or sexual intercourse compelled by force or threatâ€  
  * SUBJECTIVE not objective\! (ex. of objective is *People v. Goetz* in New York, but MPC remains subjective)  
  * NOT allowed if actor provoked the use of force against himself **in the same encounter** with the purpose of causing death or serious bodily injury  
  * NOT allowed if actor knows he can safely avoid using force by retreating or surrendering possession of a thing to a person who claims it is theirs or complying from a demand that he does not need to take anyway  
* Duty to retreat beforehand? Nowadays, retreat tends to be the default but there are some exceptions that allow stand your ground (SYG):  
  * Inside the house, when attacked by an intruder  
  * Inside the house, when attacked by a guest  
  * Much more variable: inside the house, when attacked by a co-occupant  
    * Originally many jurisdictions kept this as retreat rather than SYG, but (1) it can be hard to determine who is a close repeat guest v. co-occupant and (2) it adds greater hurdles for victims of domestic violence  
* **Perfect v. Imperfect Self-Defense** â€“ *State v. Norman*  
  * Perfect self-defense â€“ evidence, viewed in the light most favorable to the defendant, shows that at the time of the killing the defendant reasonably believed it to be necessary to kill the decedent to save herself from IMMINENT death or great bodily harm  
  * Imperfect self-defense â€“ some other circumstances (ex. defendant started the argument but decedent threatened to make it deadly)  
    * Not an acquittal that justifies the action but still helps reduce the sentence   
    * Must be a sentence of voluntary manslaughter or higher  
* Battered Women Syndrome (also *State v. Norman*)

**A2 Self-Defense**

* Was threat of harm actually **IMMINENT**? Very strong burden to meet â€“ *State v. Norman*  
* REMEMBER: Â§3.04(2)(b) limits use of deadly force to only situations where actor believes such force â€œis necessary to protect himself against death, serious bodily injury, kidnapping or sexual intercourse compelled by force or threatâ€  
  * NOT allowed if actor provoked the use of force against himself **in the same encounter** with the purpose of causing death or serious bodily injury  
  * NOT allowed if actor knows he can safely avoid using force by retreating or surrendering possession of a thing to a person who claims it is theirs or complying from a demand that he does not need to take anyway  
  * Howeverâ€¦ this is subjective not objective, so maybe odds of meeting the burden is higher than prosecution would like  
* Look to limitations on use of force under Â§3.09 â€“ ex. if defendant has reckless or negligent misguided beliefs, then this does not apply

**Police Use of Force (MPC Â§3.07)**

* Use of force is justifiable when the officer is making or assisting in making an arrest (actus reus) and **officer believes** that such force is **immediately necessary** to effect a lawful arrest (purely SUBJECTIVE) â€“ Â§3.07(1)   
* MUSTâ€¦ (Â§3.07(2(a))  
  * Make known the purpose of the arrest, or believe that it is otherwise known, or believe it cannot reasonably be made known to the person AND  
  * Have a valid warrant or believe the warrant to be valid, when applicable  
* When deadly force, MUSTâ€¦ (Â§3.07(2(b))  
  * Arrest for a felony, not misdemeanor AND  
  * Be authorized as a police officer or be assisting someone believe to be a police officer AND  
  * Believe that force used creates no substantial risk of injury to innocent people  
  * Believe that the crime for which arrest is happening involved use or threatened use of deadly force, or there is substantial risk of future use of deadly force AND  
* Whole statute is **subjective\!\!** 

**A2 Police Use of Force**

* Typically hard to respond because so much of it is subjective  
* Look to limitations on use of force under Â§3.09 â€“ ex. if officer has reckless or negligent misguided beliefs, then this does not apply

**Necessity / Choice of Lesser Evils (MPC Â§3.02)**

* Â§3.02(2) does **NOT** allow necessity for an offense using **recklessness or negligence**, when that is enough to establish culpability  
* 4 stringent standards must be met: (*US v. Schoon*)  
  * (1) they were faced with a choice of evils and chose the lesser evil  
  * (2) they acted to prevent imminent harm  
  * (3) they reasonably anticipated a direct causal relationship between their conduct and the harm to be averted; and   
  * (4) they had no legal alternatives to violating the law

**A2 Necessity / Choice of Lesser Evils**

* 4 stringent standards must be met: (*US v. Schoon*)  
  * (1) they were faced with a choice of evils and chose the lesser evil  
  * (2) they acted to prevent imminent harm  
  * (3) they reasonably anticipated a direct causal relationship between their conduct and the harm to be averted; and   
  * (4) they had no legal alternatives to violating the law  
* Â§3.02(2) does **NOT** allow necessity for an offense using **recklessness or negligence**, when that is enough to establish culpability  
* A2 Necessity in killing an **innocent bystander** â€“ necessity is only a justification for murder when the killing is committed in self-defense, so **cannot be used here** â€“ *Regina v. Dudley and Stephens*  
* A2 Necessity in **civil disobedience** â€“ necessity **does not apply here** â€“ *US v. Schoon*

## Excuses

**Necessity / Duress (MPC Â§2.09)**

* â€œPerson of **reasonable firmness in his situation** would have been unable to resistâ€ in this conduct due to coercion by use of, or threat to use, unlawful force â€“ Â§2.09(1)   
* Â§2.09(2) does **NOT** allow for duress for an offense using **recklessness or negligence** in placing themselves in this situation, when that is enough to establish culpability

**A2 Necessity / Duress**

* Strong standard of someone directly applying coercion to you through threat of force to yourself or another person â€“ Â§2.09(1)

**Insanity (MPC Â§4.01)**

* Not responsible for criminal conduct as a result of a mental disease or defect through which he â€œlacks substantial capacity either to appreciate the criminality \[wrongfulness\] of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of lawâ€ â€“ MPC Â§4.01(1)  
  * Altered the *Mâ€™Naughten* standard (â€œirresistible impulseâ€) by adding in the fact that there can rarely be complete impairment of ability to know or to control, so what is actually needed is deprivation of â€œsubstantial capacityâ€ to understand his actions / conform his conduct to the law   
* Â§4.01(2) limits this to **NOT** include abnormality through **repeated criminal or otherwise anti-social conduct**  
* Includes addiction to alcohol / drugs, in which it could also be argued that actions were not voluntary   
  * Cannot get in trouble for the status of being addicted, so must have engaged in some other act while addicted that is illegal â€“ *Robinson v. California* 

**A2 Insanity**

* Strict standard of: â€œlacks substantial capacity either to appreciate the criminality \[wrongfulness\] of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of lawâ€ â€“ MPC Â§4.01(1)  
* Â§4.01(2) limits this to **NOT** include abnormality through **repeated criminal or otherwise anti-social conduct**  
* A2 Not Voluntary due to alcohol / drugs â€“ choice to take the alcohol / drugs to begin with *was* voluntary â€“ *Powell v. Texas*

**Extreme Emotional Distress (MPC Â§210(3)(b))**

* Defense has two principal components (*People v. Casassa*, based on Â§210(3)(b))   
  * 1\. The particular defendant must have "acted under the influence of extreme emotional disturbance," (SUBJECTIVE) and   
  * 2\. There must have been "a reasonable explanation or excuse" for such extreme emotional disturbance, the reasonableness of which is to be determined from the viewpoint of a person in the defendant's situation under the circumstances as the defendant believed them to be (OBJECTIVE)  
* Does not apply if killing was a result of defendantâ€™s malevolence, rather than a reaction deserving mercy â€“ *People v. Casassa*

**A2 Extreme Emotional Distress**

* Tough burden to prove both components of the test are met\!\!  
  * Did defendant actually subjectively have extreme emotional disturbance?  
  * Was this behavior objectively reasonable given the situation?

# Policy 

## Course Themes

| How Criminal Law Entrenches Social Order |  |  |  |
| ----- | :---- | :---- | :---- |
| **How politics & morality are both hidden in the criminal law and through it exert an extraordinary influence on society and the social order** |  |  |  |
| Society often thinks of the criminal law as upholding moral values more so than other areas of the law. We often think of murder, rape, etc. as offending some moral sense of inherent or God-given human dignity (Kant). Itâ€™s an area of the law where law students have built-in conceptions of right and wrong, more so than when we first studied the merits of the Statute of Frauds. But thatâ€™s all wrongâ€¦ The criminal law **fundamentally shapes/reinforces the racial/social order in the US**. We tend to overlook this  Even that systematic racism does not capture the foundational way in which guilt and innocence are **naturalized** in our society & the criminal law has shaped our racial, gender, and class **hierarchies** and has formed our economic and political **inequalities** To understand that, we have to look **at how criminal law has served to entrench and replicate methods of oppression**  WEB Du Bois: After Reconstruction, criminal law was used to re-establish racial hierarchy in the South. Southern states enacted criminal law codes targeted at Blacks, criminalizing behavior and ensuring harsher punishments. So recently freed blacks lost their homes and property and essentially became slave laborers. Convict leasing effectively re-enslaved blacks. **Criminal law replaced property law to re-enslave blacks in the South**.  Criminal law created a new form of servitude but not in the blatantly immoral structure of property law, but under the veil of a criminal conviction. Sprawling prisons spread in the South, with convicts forced to labor. Law enforcement, together with lynch mobs, institutionalized terror in the South. **Criminal law was the linchpin to dispossess blacks, deliberately and intentionally, restructuring society as a substitute for chattel slavery.** E.g., Alabama Constitutional Convention of 1901: disenfranchise anyone convicted of a felony or misdemeanor or crime of moral turpitude (eventually struck down by Rehnquist court) since moral turpitude was used to disenfranchise blacks â€œCertainly the 'crimes' and' offences' on which judgement is passed are juridical objects defined by the code, but judgement is also passed on the passions, instincts, anomalies, infirmities, maladjustments, effects of environment or heredity; acts of aggression are punished, so also, through them, is aggressivity; rape, but at the same time perversions; murders, but also drives and desires.â€ (Foucault, *Discipline and Punish*, 17\) **â€œ**According to one theory, domination occurs when the ruling class gains the consent of the dominated classes through a system of ideas that reinforces the morality or inevitability of the existing order. This â€˜interest theoryâ€™ sees ideology as a consciously wielded weapon, an intellectual tool that a group uses to enhance its political power by institutionalizing a particular view of reality.â€ (Lawrence, â€˜Id, Egoâ€ 326\) Harder today to see the fine-grained ways in which the criminal law continues to oppress. Because of the objectivity, universality of being convicted of a crime, the criminal law operates under the radar to push morality and politics into the law in a hidden way.  **So, you must be finely attuned to the way the criminal law naturalizes crime.** The category of crime can easily be made objective, universal. We tend to think of crimes in objective, universal terms â€“ as things which have always been prohibited in human experience from time immemorial. So, we think the guilt associated with that category is a natural, objective marker of moral condemnation.  But what ends up being considered legitimate use of force (e.g., stand your ground laws) or what is considered consent to sexual intercourse (e.g., marital rape exception) or what is considered the legitimate use of law enforcement force (e.g., non-indictments of cops in Breonna Taylor shooting) show the prescription in general terms may be of time immemorial â€“ but not their interpretation and application. We donâ€™t see the ways criminal law is used to engage in political and social action.  **The criminal act is the most powerful device for social and moral condemnation** Punishment reflects who we are as a society**; Punishment practices need to be understood as social structures.**  The building blocks of criminal law (the elements of crimes) are very simple. But in addition to learning these, we did not understand *justice*.  |  |  |  |
| **Our culture** |  |  | Contemporary Western, European, Judeo-Christian culture.  i.e., â€œEuropean, scientific, rational, and technical culture,â€ with its globalizing tendencies.â€ (Foucault) Marked by hierarchies: patriarchy, systemic racism, class order, etc. CRT: **problems of race in this country are structural, deep, foundational**, and cannot simply be fixed by individual correctives. Not just bad apples.  |
| **Power of norms** |  |  | Robinson & Darley: â€œCriminal lawâ€¦ influences the powerful social forces of normative behavior control through its central role in **the creation of shared norms**.â€ (CB, 121\) â€œPerhaps more than any other society, ours relies on the criminal law for norm-nurturing. Our greater cultural diversity means that we cannot expect a stable pre-existing consensus on the contours of condemnable conduct that is found in more homogenous societies.â€  Lawâ€™s threat of punishment can induce conformity through more than just cost-benefit calculation of the rational actor â€œPeople obey the law (1) because they fear the disapproval of their social group if they violate the law, and (2) because they generally see themselves as moral beings who want to do the right thing as they perceive it.â€ (CB, 121\) Cognitive psychology: â€œthe cultureâ€¦ transmits certain beliefs and preferences. Because these beliefs are so much a part of the culture, they are not experienced as explicit lessons. Instead, they seem part of the individualâ€™s rational ordering of her perceptions of the world.â€ (Lawrence) By shaping norms, criminal law *shapes us*. It ensures members of society voluntarily uphold the social order (like Antilochus).  â€œFoucault demonstrates how deeply and seamlessly judgment is woven into the fabric of culture, in domains we would never have imagined: how, in realms apparently so distant from the public sphere of politicsâ€”our private bedrooms and closetsâ€”**cultural norms are woven into our daily lived experience and shape our deepest subjective reality**; how they pervade our consciousness and experience of life; how they **shape our very epistemology**â€”the way we see and understand the world, distinguish between science and opinion, make claims to truth; and how much work and social practice it takes to make these cultural ways of being natural and invisible throughout our lived experience.â€ (Harcourt, Intro to Lectures on Sexuality, 3\)  â€œThe conclusion to be drawn from this is that **morality does not exist in peopleâ€™s heads; it is inscribed in power relations** and only the modification of these power relations can bring about the modification of morality.â€ (*The Punitive Society*) (quoted in Harcourt, Intro to Lectures on Sexuality, 4\) â€œWhat is key is that these are all practicesâ€”social practicesâ€”and not simply things going on in our heads. . . They are the product of social practices that shape the very basis of how we draw lines and form judgmentsâ€”including those of truth, those that separate science from mere opinion or ideology.â€ (Harcourt, Intro to Lectures on Sexuality, 9\) Crime has come to be defined as a **moral wrong**. We used to punish people for their acts. Now, we punish people for who they are.  Framing crime as a moral failure of the criminal keeps people from questioning and criticizing the penitentiary system and the larger criminal justice system.  |
| **Application to criminal law** |  |  | Just as Foucault shows how norms are woven into culture, in criminal law cultural norms are woven into our daily experiences and shape our deepest subjective reality The norms & moral values of our culture infuse the criminal law. The norms of our culture are expressed and reflected in between the lines, in the subconscious value judgments being made  E.g., Whatâ€™s adequate provocation? Answer is influenced by patriarchy, monogamy, etc. The worst offenses in Blackstone (e.g., wife killing husband) reflects a culture marked by patriarchy |
| **Legitimation**  |  |  | â€œWe conclude, with gloomy irony, that the Supreme Courtâ€™s Eighth Amendment jurisprudence, originally promoted by self-consciously abolitionist litigators and advanced b reformist members of the Court, not only has failed to meet its purported goal of rationalizing the imposition of the death penalty, but also **may have helped to stabilize and entrench the practice of capital punishment** in the US.â€ (Steiker, 360\) Courtâ€™s jurisprudence has had effect of **legitimating DP**: **Internal legitimation**:  Law is a crutch that allows people to do what they feel is unjust (*See* **Robert Cover** on abolitionist judges applying Fugitive Slave Act)  Death penalty discourse and doctrines makes the system appear more rational and fair to actors within the legal system, giving a false aura of science to the *moral* task of deciding life or death (Steiker, 431\) Sentencing judges & juries feel less ultimate responsibility for imposing death penalty, since they know thatâ€™s only the first step in a lengthy chain of review (434)  \[maybe this also applies to acquittal of Goetz, Zimmerman; no-bill of killers of Brown, Garner\] **Particular external legitimation**: Complexity of the system **makes public more comfortable with death penalty** that otherwise would be  â€œThe public develops a strong but false sense that many levels of safeguards protect against unjust or arbitrary executions. They are thus likely to accept any executions that finally make it through the system as being more than fair enough.â€ (436) **General external legitimation**: CP legitimates use of physical force by state, thus legitimating state power generally.  Procedure creates an â€œideology of justiceâ€ that disguises class interest of the law & encourages public to hold false or exaggerated belief in fairness of the social system (*See* **Hay** on CP in 18th c. England) (432) Reason for the Courtâ€™s approach: **House built by warring architects**: Internal dynamics, as centrists, lacking a vision of their own, have been pulled in the opposite directions of two minority absolutist wings without choosing either (437) |
| **How criminal law reflects hierarchies** |  |  | There is a through line from slavery ğŸ¡ª Jim Crow ğŸ¡ª carceral society  Slavery ğŸ¡ª convict leasing ğŸ¡ª mass incarceration  Lynching ğŸ¡ª capital punishment  **â€œ**The criminal law and its enforcement are **primarily instruments of social ordering** predominantly deployed **to keep African-Americans and other persons of color in a condition of second-class citizenship**.â€ (BH, NA) Mass incarceration, policing etc. serve to segregate and weaken Black society  WEB Du Bois â€œdemonstrated that the enforcement of the criminal law after Emancipation was used as one of the main weapons to re-enslave freed Black women and men.â€ (BH NA, 4\) Antebellum USA: Race of the perpetrator & victim dictated whether conduct was considered criminal Laws enabled whites to punish enslaved Blacks w/ impunity, including execution (but not vice versa) Legislatures explicitly deprived enslaved people equal protection of the common law when whites abused them: Thus, Blacks could be perpetrators, not victims All these forms of discrimination build on each other to shape society (mass incarceration of Black men ğŸ¡ª perception that Black men are dangerous ğŸ¡ª acquittal of Zimmerman, Goetz) Enabled by â€œreasonablenessâ€ & other standards that give jury discretion Even if you ban explicit racial language, defense lawyers can use code words, which, thanks to US culture, trigger certain perceptions & judgments (e.g., Zimmerman lawyer presenting photo of muscular Martin ğŸ¡ª Black men dangerous ğŸ¡ª Martin posed threat to Zimmerman)  |
| **Crime & punishment** |  |  | The criminal justice system is not about redressing the harms associated with crime. Itâ€™s about imposing an unjust social and racial hierarchy on US society. In other words, punishment is not a response to criminal behaviorâ€”itâ€™s a mode of governance and control.  â€œWe must first rid ourselves of the illusion that punishment is above all (if not exclusively) a means of reducing crimeâ€¦â€ (Foucault, *Discipline and Punish*, 24\) Punishment as a complex social function Punishment reflects who we are as a society. Punishment practices need to be understood as social structures, reflecting social values & racial/economic hierarchies. (Foucault, *Discipline and Punish*, 24\) 18th c. to present-day, move from punishment of the body (barbaric) to punishment of the soul (punishing better). Punishment is not above all a means of reducing crime; it is a way of controlling people, throughout society, in an orthopedic fashion, making them docile. (Foucault, *Discipline and Punish*) All these forms of discrimination build on each other to shape society (mass incarceration of Black men ğŸ¡ª perception that Black men are dangerous ğŸ¡ª acquittal of Zimmerman, Goetz Punishment practices serve economic needs (i.e., need for labor) E.g., example from the Frankfurt school of a letter from the French King stating that, because of his need for oarsmen, he wished the public prosecutor of Paris to have criminal judged quickly **Harm**: the harms defined by the criminal system reflect what the dominant groups in society believe to be good for society. Perceptions of harms reflect existing hierarchies.  Goal: prevent have-nots from taking from the haves Racial & class dynamics shape perceptions of harms (thatâ€™s why street crime is prosecuted more aggressively than white collar crime) â€œThe very notion of harm at the heart of criminal law enforcementâ€”the very measure of â€œan even-handed wayâ€â€”is inflected by the normative structure of the existing social and racial order.â€ (BH, NA, 22\) E.g., theft is bad because we live in capitalist society & it takes wealth from those who have it (even if distribution is inequitable)  |
| **Reform?** |  |  | Reform the criminal justice system? Or abolish it? Reforms are a distraction from abolition  â€œThis progressive position rests on unstable foundations. The reason is that the existing social and racial order shapes the very conceptions of harms and violence that lie at the heart of the enforcement of criminal law. In other words, the perception of harm and violence associated with criminality is determined by race, gender, class, and other relations of power in society. It is not possible to talk about the harms caused by crime in a vacuum. The â€œharms caused by crimeâ€ are artifacts of the present social condition and racial hierarchies.â€ (BH, NA, 20\) â€œWe would need to look beyond restorative justiceâ€”or reimagine itâ€”because it remains today too wedded to the existing understandings of harm shaped by our current society traversed by systemic racism and sexism.â€ (BH, NA, 36\) â€œPragmatic thinkers will resist this invitation as overly utopian. Rather than imagine a just social order, the pragmatist will respond that we should extract racismâ€”even systemic racismâ€”from the practices and institutions, and enforce the criminal law on a race-neutral basis.â€ BUT â€œAmerican society, without racial hierarchy, would be an entirely different society.â€ (BH, NA 23\) Abolition would result in: Better schools, more healthcare, justice system based on reconciliation, not retribution |
| **Examples of punishment as a reflection of society & its hierarchies** |  |  |  |
| **Felony murder rule** | Footnote to ***SernÃ©*** quotes Edward Coke, Institutes 56 (1644): If a man accidentally shoots another while hunting & trespassing on anotherâ€™s land, thatâ€™s felony-murder. If a man accidentally shoots another while hunting on *his own land*, thatâ€™s just an accidental killing. Shows class/property dimension: What rends the same act punishable is the fact that youâ€™re not the property owner.  Felony murder in part comes from class; woven into the law in ways we rarely see  Felony murder operates as a way to **entrench social order**, including systemic racism, into the law  Maybe thatâ€™s why society was ready to take Adnan Khan, a homeless drop-out, and put him in prison for the rest of his life \[incapacitation\] |  |  |
| **Homicide** | Laws of homicide as form of social ordering (i.e., reflecting & reinforcing social hierarchy) Laws of homicide do more than define homicide. | **Manslaughter** | ***State v. Williams*** (Wa. Ct. | **Sentencing guidelines** | Risk scores determine different levels of punishment in some jurisdictions (e.g., VA rape sentencing) Maps on to socioeconomic, racial categories (e.g., more points for unemployment or for lack of education past 9th grade) |  |  |
| **Punishment**  | Vitiello:  â€œIn **Puritan** America, the law was used to advance the dominant religious beliefs and to enforce "proper standards of moral behavior." Based on the Calvinist belief in the innate depravity of human beings, the criminal law served to keep people from temptation.â€ (CB, 122-123) â€œ**Quaker** views contrasted sharply with the Puritan conception of the criminal law. Early in our history, the Quakers led a movement away from capital and corporal punishment to a system of workhouses and prisons. Viewed as grim in retrospect, that system was generally enlightened by comparison to earlier treatment of criminals. At root, it was based on an **optimism about human capacity for transformation**. Like proponents of the medical model, Quakers believed that crime was the product of society, rather than a result of inherent sinfulness. But the method chosen for transformation was not "treatment." Instead, they believed that the offender could be **reformed through a process of rationality**. Freed from the corrupting influences and permitted to reflect on moral questions, the offender could be "restored to fellowship with God and humanity.â€™â€ |  |  |
